questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: All of the following are current assets except:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Goodwill is a long-term asset, and cash and inventories are current assets.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Goodwill is a long-term asset, and cash and inventories are current assets.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question:
Deferred tax liabilities result when:

  1. taxable income in a period is less than reported financial statement income before taxes.
  2. items of expense are included in financial statement income in earlier periods than those for which taxable income is reported.
  3. straight-line depreciation methods are used for tax purposes and accelerated methods are employed for financial statement purposes.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Deferred tax liabilities result when, for a given period, taxable income and the associated income tax payable are less than the reported financial statement income before taxes and the associated income tax expense. Incorrect because if items of expense are included in financial statement income in earlier periods than those for which taxable income is reported, then the financial statement income and associated reported income tax expense will be less than taxable income and actual income tax payable. A deferred tax liability occurs only in the opposite case, when taxable income and income tax payable are smaller. Deferred tax liabilities result from timing differences between financial statement income and taxable income when taxable income is lower than financial statement income, not higher. Incorrect because straight-line depreciation methods result in lower depreciation expense than accelerated methods. This approach would produce higher taxable income than financial statement income, with no resulting deferred tax liability. Analyzing Balance Sheets explain the financial reporting and disclosures related to non-current liabilities
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Deferred tax liabilities result when, for a given period, taxable income and the associated income tax payable are less than the reported financial statement income before taxes and the associated income tax expense.

  2. Incorrect because if items of expense are included in financial statement income in earlier periods than those for which taxable income is reported, then the financial statement income and associated reported income tax expense will be less than taxable income and actual income tax payable. A deferred tax liability occurs only in the opposite case, when taxable income and income tax payable are smaller. Deferred tax liabilities result from timing differences between financial statement income and taxable income when taxable income is lower than financial statement income, not higher.

  3. Incorrect because straight-line depreciation methods result in lower depreciation expense than accelerated methods. This approach would produce higher taxable income than financial statement income, with no resulting deferred tax liability.

Analyzing Balance Sheets

  • explain the financial reporting and disclosures related to non-current liabilities

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: The initial measurement of goodwill is most likely affected by:

choices.C: the fair value of the acquirer’s assets and liabilities.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Initially, goodwill is measured as the difference between the purchase price paid for an acquisition and the fair value of the acquired, not acquiring, company’s net assets (identifiable assets less liabilities).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Initially, goodwill is measured as the difference between the purchase price paid for an acquisition and the fair value of the acquired, not acquiring, company’s net assets (identifiable assets less liabilities).

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question:
Use the following common-size balance sheet information to answer the question below.

Assets Company X Company Y Company Z
Cash and cash equivalents 15.6% 12.0% 2.0%
Marketable securities 3.4% 5.1% 12.0%
Trade and other receivables 10.9% 12.7% 4.8%
Other non-financial assets 14.3% 11.7% 7.4%
Total current assets 44.2% 41.5% 26.2%
Goodwill 1.6% 2.2% 28.8%
Intangible assets 17.6% 7.0% 24.0%
Property, plant, and equipment 17.7% 25.3% 8.2%
Other financial assets 12.4% 24.0% 9.6%
Other non-financial assets 0.3% 0.0% 2.1%
Deferred tax assets 6.2% 0.0% 1.1%
Total non-current assets 55.8% 58.5% 73.8%
Total assets 100.0% 100.0% 100.0%
Liabilities and shareholders’ equity
Trade and other payables 3.4% 3.5% 2.1%
Bank loans and other financial liabilities 8.4% 3.2% 6.0%
Other non-financial liabilities 5.0% 11.7% 9.0%
Deferred income 11.8% 9.8% 0.0%
Total current liabilities 28.6% 28.2% 17.1%
Financial liabilities 18.4% 18.3% 17.4%
Other non-financial liabilities 12.8% 5.7% 7.9%
Deferred tax liabilities 2.5% 4.2% 18.6%
Total non-current liabilities 33.7% 27.5% 43.9%
Total liabilities 62.3% 55.7% 61.0%
Total shareholders’ equity 37.7% 44.3% 39.0%
Total liabilities and shareholders’ equity 100.0% 100.0% 100.0%

Which company is most likely to have grown through acquisitions?

  1. Company X
  2. Company Y
  3. Company Z
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because Company X has 1.6% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z. Incorrect because Company Y has 2.2% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z. Correct. Company Z has the highest percentage of assets in goodwill at 28.8%, with the other companies having much smaller percentages (1.6% for Company X and 2.2% for Company Y). Because goodwill is an asset recognized by acquirers purchasing companies at prices above the fair value of their identifiable assets and liabilities, it is most likely, given the great disparity in goodwill, that of these firms, Company Z has grown through acquisitions. Analyzing Balance Sheets calculate and interpret common-size balance sheets and related financial ratios
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because Company X has 1.6% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z.

  2. Incorrect because Company Y has 2.2% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z.

  3. Correct. Company Z has the highest percentage of assets in goodwill at 28.8%, with the other companies having much smaller percentages (1.6% for Company X and 2.2% for Company Y). Because goodwill is an asset recognized by acquirers purchasing companies at prices above the fair value of their identifiable assets and liabilities, it is most likely, given the great disparity in goodwill, that of these firms, Company Z has grown through acquisitions.

Analyzing Balance Sheets

  • calculate and interpret common-size balance sheets and related financial ratios

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: For financial assets classified as trading securities, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.B: They flow through income into retained earnings.
choices.C: They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. For financial assets classified as trading securities, unrealized gains and losses are reported on the income statement and flow to shareholders’ equity as part of retained earnings.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. For financial assets classified as trading securities, unrealized gains and losses are reported on the income statement and flow to shareholders’ equity as part of retained earnings.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: For financial assets classified as available for sale, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.C: They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. For financial assets classified as available for sale, unrealized gains and losses are not recorded on the income statement and instead are part of other comprehensive income. Accumulated other comprehensive income is a component of shareholders’ equity.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. For financial assets classified as available for sale, unrealized gains and losses are not recorded on the income statement and instead are part of other comprehensive income. Accumulated other comprehensive income is a component of shareholders’ equity.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: For financial assets classified as held to maturity, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.C: They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Financial assets classified as held to maturity are measured at amortized cost. Gains and losses are recognized only when realized.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Financial assets classified as held to maturity are measured at amortized cost. Gains and losses are recognized only when realized.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: A company has total liabilities of GBP35 million and total stockholders’ equity of GBP55 million. Total liabilities are represented on a vertical common-size balance sheet by a percentage closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Vertical common-size analysis involves stating each balance sheet item as a percentage of total assets. Total assets are the sum of total liabilities (GBP35 million) and total stockholders’ equity (GBP55 million), or GBP90 million. Total liabilities are shown on a vertical common-size balance sheet as (GBP35 million ÷ GBP90 million) ≈ 39%.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Vertical common-size analysis involves stating each balance sheet item as a percentage of total assets. Total assets are the sum of total liabilities (GBP35 million) and total stockholders’ equity (GBP55 million), or GBP90 million. Total liabilities are shown on a vertical common-size balance sheet as (GBP35 million ÷ GBP90 million) ≈ 39%.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: Which of the following would an analyst most likely be able to determine from a common-size analysis of a company’s balance sheet over several periods?

choices.A: An increase or decrease in sales
choices.B: An increase or decrease in financial leverage
choices.C: A more efficient or less efficient use of assets

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. A common-size balance sheet analysis provides information about the composition of the balance sheet and it changes over time. As a result, it can provide information about an increase or decrease in a company’s financial leverage.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. A common-size balance sheet analysis provides information about the composition of the balance sheet and it changes over time. As a result, it can provide information about an increase or decrease in a company’s financial leverage.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: Defining total asset turnover as revenue divided by average total assets, all else equal, impairment write-downs of long-lived assets owned by a company will most likely result in an increase for that company in:

choices.A: the debt-to-equity ratio but not the total asset turnover.
choices.B: the total asset turnover but not the debt-to-equity ratio.
choices.C: both the debt-to-equity ratio and the total asset turnover.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Impairment write-downs reduce equity in the denominator of the debt-to-equity ratio but do not affect debt, so the debt-to-equity ratio is expected to increase. Impairment write-downs reduce total assets but do not affect revenue. Thus, total asset turnover is expected to increase.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Impairment write-downs reduce equity in the denominator of the debt-to-equity ratio but do not affect debt, so the debt-to-equity ratio is expected to increase. Impairment write-downs reduce total assets but do not affect revenue. Thus, total asset turnover is expected to increase.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: An investor concerned about a company’s ability to meet its near-term obligations is most likely to calculate the:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The current ratio provides a comparison of assets that can be turned into cash relatively quickly and liabilities that must be paid within one year. The other ratios are more suited to evaluate longer-term concerns.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The current ratio provides a comparison of assets that can be turned into cash relatively quickly and liabilities that must be paid within one year. The other ratios are more suited to evaluate longer-term concerns.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: The most stringent test of a company’s liquidity is its:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The cash ratio determines how much of a company’s near-term obligations can be settled with existing amounts of cash and marketable securities.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The cash ratio determines how much of a company’s near-term obligations can be settled with existing amounts of cash and marketable securities.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question: An investor worried about a company’s long-term solvency would most likely examine its:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The debt-to-equity ratio, a solvency ratio, is an indicator of financial risk.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The debt-to-equity ratio, a solvency ratio, is an indicator of financial risk.

questions.title: Analyzing Balance Sheets
questions.question:
Consider the common-size balance sheets in Exhibit 1 for Company A, Company B, as well as the industry average. Which statement is correct?

Exhibit 1:

Balance Sheet and Industry Average

      Company A   Company B   Industry Average
ASSETS
Current assets            
  Cash and cash equivalents   5   5   7
  Marketable securities   5   0   2
  Accounts receivable, net   5   15   12
  Inventories   15   20   16
  Prepaid expenses   5   15   11
Total current assets   35   55   48
  Property, plant, and equipment, net   40   35   37
  Goodwill   25   0   8
  Other assets   0   10   7
Total assets 100   100   100
LIABILITIES AND SHAREHOLDERS’ EQUITY
Current liabilities            
  Accounts payable   10   10   10
  Short-term debt   25   10   15
  Accrued expenses   0   5   3
Total current liabilities   35   25   28
  Long-term debt   45   20   28
  Other non-current liabilities   0   10   7
Total liabilities   80   55   63
  Total shareholders’ equity   20   45   37
Total liabilities and shareholders’ equity   100   100   100

choices.A: Company A has below-average liquidity risk.
choices.B: Company B has above-average solvency risk.
choices.C: Company A has made one or more acquisitions.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The presence of goodwill on Company A’s balance sheet signifies that it has made one or more acquisitions in the past. The current, cash, and quick ratios are lower for Company A than for the sector average. These lower liquidity ratios imply above-average liquidity risk. The total debt, long-term debt-to-equity, debt-to-equity, and financial leverage ratios are lower for Company B than for the sector average. These lower solvency ratios imply below-average solvency risk. Current ratio is (35 ÷ 35) = 1.00 for Company A, versus (48 ÷ 28) = 1.71 for the sector average. Cash ratio is (5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.29 for Company A, versus (7 + 2) ÷28 = 0.32 for the sector average. Quick ratio is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.43 for Company A, versus (7 + 2 + 12) ÷28 = 0.75 for the sector average. Total debt ratio is (55 ÷ 100) = 0.55 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 100) = 0.63 for the sector average. Long-term debt-to-equity ratio is (20 ÷ 45) = 0.44 for Company B, versus (28 ÷ 37) = 0.76 for the sector average. Debt-to-equity ratio is (55 ÷ 45) = 1.22 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 37) = 1.70 for the sector average. Financial leverage ratio is (100 ÷ 45) = 2.22 for Company B, versus (100 ÷ 37) = 2.70 for the sector average.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The presence of goodwill on Company A’s balance sheet signifies that it has made one or more acquisitions in the past. The current, cash, and quick ratios are lower for Company A than for the sector average. These lower liquidity ratios imply above-average liquidity risk. The total debt, long-term debt-to-equity, debt-to-equity, and financial leverage ratios are lower for Company B than for the sector average. These lower solvency ratios imply below-average solvency risk.

Current ratio is (35 ÷ 35) = 1.00 for Company A, versus (48 ÷ 28) = 1.71 for the sector average.Cash ratio is (5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.29 for Company A, versus (7 + 2) ÷28 = 0.32 for the sector average.Quick ratio is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.43 for Company A, versus (7 + 2 + 12) ÷28 = 0.75 for the sector average.Total debt ratio is (55 ÷ 100) = 0.55 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 100) = 0.63 for the sector average.Long-term debt-to-equity ratio is (20 ÷ 45) = 0.44 for Company B, versus (28 ÷ 37) = 0.76 for the sector average.Debt-to-equity ratio is (55 ÷ 45) = 1.22 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 37) = 1.70 for the sector average.Financial leverage ratio is (100 ÷ 45) = 2.22 for Company B, versus (100 ÷ 37) = 2.70 for the sector average.

Total shareholders’ equity 20 45 37

The quick ratio for Company A is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The quick ratio is defined as (Cash and cash equivalents + Marketable securities + receivables) ÷ Current liabilities. For Company A, this calculation is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.43.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The quick ratio is defined as (Cash and cash equivalents + Marketable securities + receivables) ÷ Current liabilities. For Company A, this calculation is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.43.

The financial leverage ratio for Company B is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The financial leverage ratio is defined as Total assets ÷ Total equity. For Company B, total assets are 100 and total equity is 45; hence, the financial leverage ratio is 100 ÷ 45 = 2.22.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The financial leverage ratio is defined as Total assets ÷ Total equity. For Company B, total assets are 100 and total equity is 45; hence, the financial leverage ratio is 100 ÷ 45 = 2.22.

Which ratio indicates lower liquidity risk for Company A compared with Company B?
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. A higher cash ratio reflects lower liquidity risk. The cash ratio is defined as (Cash + Marketable securities) ÷ Current liabilities. Company A’s cash ratio, (5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.29, is higher than (5 + 0) ÷ 25 = 0.20 for Company B.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. A higher cash ratio reflects lower liquidity risk. The cash ratio is defined as (Cash + Marketable securities) ÷ Current liabilities. Company A’s cash ratio, (5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.29, is higher than (5 + 0) ÷ 25 = 0.20 for Company B.
